thread.title: Dollar jumps as GDP report, Fed point to rate hike
thread.title_full: Dollar jumps as GDP report, Fed point to rate hike - MarketWatch

author: By     Sara Sjolin   and   Hiroyuki Kachi
title: Dollar jumps as GDP report, Fed point to rate hike
text:
The dollar was bouncing higher against its main rivals Thursday on news that the U.S. economy picked up modestly in the spring , expanding at an annual 2.3% rate in the second quarter.
New methods in how the government calculates gross-domestic product also showed the economy grew 0.6% in the first quarter instead of contracting by 0.2%.
Thursday’s reports came on the heels of a slightly hawkish statement from the Federal Open Market Committee , which on Wednesday opened the door for a potential rate increase in September.
The GDP data; although showing unspectacular growth, combined with the policy statement at the conclusion of the Federal Open Market Committee, are being read by some as an indication that the data-dependent Federal Reserve could be a step closer to raising interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade .
A rate hike would be a boon for the buck , because it would increase returns on deposits, making the currency more attractive to traders. The greenback has recently moved higher on expectations the first monetary tightening may come sometime this year. Although, the Fed’s Chairwoman Janet Yellen has tried to convey that the pace of rate hikes would be very measured after the first increase.
The buck USDJPY, +0.32% advanced to ¥124.34, its highest since July 21, up from ¥123.94 late Wednesday in New York. The dollar EURUSD, -0.5735% also strengthened against the euro, which fell to $1.0923 from $1.0986 in New York overnight.
The WSJ Dollar Index BUXX, +0.46% a measure of the dollar against a basket of 16 major currencies, was up 0.5% at 88.82, while the ICE dollar index DXY, +0.40% which measures the dollar against six rivals, tacked on 0.6% to 97.5880.
The upbeat trading mood in the dollar followed a positive session on Wednesday , when the Fed left its benchmark short-term interest rate near zero, but dropped several hints that it is close to seeing enough improvement in the job market to prompt officials to raise the rate as early as September.
Hilsenrath: Fed on course for September rate rise (3:56) Jon Hilsenrath has analysis of the Federal Reserve's move to keep rates near zero. The Fed cited continued improvement in the U.S. job market as an indication a September rate increase is likely.
For months, Fed officials have said they wanted to see “additional improvement in the labor market” before being convinced it is time to raise rates. In Wednesday’s statement, they said they wanted to see “some” additional improvement, suggesting they see themselves nearing their threshold on the jobs front for action.
“They didn’t say it clearly but investors can slightly smell (a rate increase) in September,” said Koji Fukaya, chief executive at FPG Securities.

In other currencies, the pound GBPUSD, +0.0256% rose to $1.5608 from $1.5604 late in New York on Wednesday.
